name: Wubi for Ubuntu 22.04.1 (rev. 345)
body:
md5sum: 674099c1452e689ad2399f5323055ee2
sha256sum: 6ea83267b591a542604288eba4eb4e199b1351c984ea25f391db21d1e72d9725

Supported features:
- Version [22.04.1](http://releases.ubuntu.com/22.04.1) with automatic download, other 22.04(.x) with manual download
- Ubuntu, Kubuntu(*), Ubuntu Studio, Ubuntu MATE, Xubuntu, Lubuntu(**), Ubuntu  Kylin, Ubuntu Budgie, all versions [64 bit only](https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-release/2017-September/004212.html)
- various distros/versions with manual download (desktop environments "Wubi", "Wubi lz", "Wubi EFI", "Wubi MD5", "Wubi gz", "Wubi SHA256", "Wubi lz4")
- UEFI (64 bit + 32 bit), legacy BIOS
- Fast Startup and Hibernate
- Secure Boot
- Parted 3.2
- MMC + NVMe devices
- replacement for lupin-support
- disk sizes > 30 GB

Release changes:

  * Bump to 22.04.1 (#316)
  * workaround for missing boot option debian-installer/custom-installation= (#305)
  * replacement for missing package lupin-support (#305)
  * Change link for www.voidspace.org.uk (#289)

Known issues:

* Manual reboot is necessary after second part of installation.
* installer is not compatible with older versions of Ubuntu 
possible workaraound: change boot option "file=/../isodevice" to "file=/isodevice" see [boot options](https://github.com/hakuna-m/wubiuefi/wiki/FAQ#how-can-i-set-boot-options-)
* (*) Kubuntu has no progress bar during second part of installation.
* (**) Lubuntu installer and other distros withoout Ubiquity do not work. So only live environment is available. see (#232 , #149, #121)

development release, further fixes are planed with next release (#310)

name: Wubi for Ubuntu 20.04 (rev 339-2)
body:
md5sum: e698ea71add0a98ef4e3fb9c95e9195a
sha256sum: e09c2b978b55c45d0a945bf561cf20c2c020a167784bff404a72446dd435906a

Release changes: see [2004r339](https://github.com/hakuna-m/wubiuefi/releases/tag/2004r339)
Branch changes: 2nd independent Wubi install

|  | 2004r339 | 2004r339-2 |
| --- | --- | --- |
| installation folder | ubuntu | ubuntu**2** |
| EFI folder | /EFI/ubuntu/wubildr | /EFI/ubuntu**2**/wubildr |
| boot loader files | wubild**r**.mbr, wubild**r** | wubild**2**.mbr, wubild**2** |
| application name in Windows registry entry | Wubi | Wubi**2** |

**Note: 2004r339-2 is only needed for a second  install. It doesn't remove 2004r339 or other versions within folder ubuntu. If there is no existing install or you want to replace an existing install of 2004r339 or other versions within folder ubuntu, please use [2004r339](https://github.com/hakuna-m/wubiuefi/releases/tag/2004r339) instead.**

```
Go back to the menu and resume partitioning?

```

```
Go back to the menu and correct this problem?

```

```
 Go back to the menu and correct this problem?

 It is normally required for you to create a separate partition for the boot
 loader code in order to boot your system in EFI mode. This partition should
 be marked for use as an "EFI boot partition" and should be at least 35 MB
 in size. Note that this is not the same as a partition mounted on /boot.
 .
 If you do not go back to the partitioning menu and correct this error, boot
 loader installation may fail later, although it may still be possible to
 install the boot loader to a partition. 
```

name: Wubi for Ubuntu 18.04 (rev 331 rEFInd testing branch)
body:
md5sum: 52633d46bb38492c9ad170fdccff8a90
sha256sum: 0e84d4239ba3379b17ae68810003058220b9ae9fc354df21ec22c7cce01a3501

Supported features:

see [1804r331](https://github.com/hakuna-m/wubiuefi/releases/tag/1804r331)

Special notes for the rEFInd branch:

- Differences: 
  - in BIOS mode: no difference but also no advantage
  - in UEFI mode: the additional boot manager [rEFInd](http://www.rodsbooks.com/refind) is a workaround for some GRUB problems

The Wubiuefi configuration for rEFInd provides:
  - a boot entry for the installed OS (environment icon, e.g. Ubuntu icon) 
  - a boot entry for Windows (Windows icon)
  - optional boot entries for other installed OS
  - a boot entry for GRUB (penguin icon)
  - a boot entry for the MokManager (key icon)
  - ......

The boot entry for the installed OS provides boot options like GRUB menu (see [Adjusting Boot Options](http://www.rodsbooks.com/refind/using.html#boot_options) ).

If the boot entry for the installed OS does not work, the boot entry for GRUB provides the standard menus. There are reports that the standard GRUB menus do work even if they don't work work without rEFInd.

sha256sum: a24a8f91a46b1024647c32f12b4912521eca59a7d0ba9a0756cc3ca984a1cc71

Supported features:
- Version [17.04](http://releases.ubuntu.com/17.04) with automatic download. 
- Ubuntu, Kubuntu (*), Lubuntu, Ubuntu Studio, Ubuntu GNOME, Ubuntu MATE, Xubuntu, Ubuntu  Kylin, Ubuntu Budgie
- various distros/versions with manual download (desktop environments "Wubi", "Wubi EFI", "Wubi MD5", "Wubi gz", "Wubi SHA256")
- UEFI (64 bit + 32 bit), legacy BIOS
- Fast Startup and Hibernate
- Secure Boot
- Parted 3.2
- MMC + NVMe devices
- package lupin-support (for Lubuntu and Ubuntu Studio)

Release changes:
- native disk support ( #49 )

Test results:

- in UEFI mode:
  - internal SD card reader (++)
  - internal HDD (+)
  - external USB keyboard (+)
  - chain loading (e.g. Windows menu entry) (-) 
- in BIOS mode:
  - native disk driver are still disabled because we have not found a working configuration (-) 

(++) does work with native disk support and does not work without native disk support.
(+) does work with native disk support and does work without native disk support.
(-) does not work with native disk support and does work without native disk support.
    
(*) Note: Kubuntu needs a workaround ( #10 ).

Note: [Release EOL](https://wiki.ubuntu.com/ReleaseEndOfLife)
